    fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);

    // process line.

    int sum =0;

    char *token = strtok(line, " \t\n");

    while (token != NULL) {

        int num = atoi(token);

        sum += num;

        token = strtok(NULL, " \t\n");

    }

    if (sum >1) c++;

}

But need to be careful with possible leading/trailing spaces, but the strtok with " \t\n" should handle that.

Second step processing:

Check if the set of characters has size 2. Then check each count is 2.

So first, get the length of s_second.

if (len !=4) → then output "No".

Wait, but the code doesn't check the length. Let me see:

Suppose the length is 3 → then the set can have 2 characters, but counts can't both be 2 (sum would be 4). So the code would output "No".

Thus, the code's logic will automatically reject it. So in C, perhaps it's better to proceed as per the code's logic.

So steps for second step:

Initialize an array to count characters.

int count[256] = {0};

for (int i=0; i < len; i++) {

    char ch = s_second[i];

    count[ch]++;

}

// Now find the unique characters.

for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

}

if (unique !=2) → output "No".

Else:

}

if (valid) → output "Yes", else "No".

Thus, in code:

for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

}

if (unique !=2) {

    strcpy(second_output, "No");

} else {

}

Now, the third step's input is the second_output (either "Yes" or "No").

We need to process this string.

Third step processing:

Take the second_output string, process it as per the third code.

First, get its length.

int len_third = strlen(second_output);

Initialize even0, even1, odd0, odd1 to 0.

for (int i=0; i < len_third; i++) {

    char c = second_output[i];

    if (i%2 ==0) { // even index

        if (c == '0') even0++;

        else if (c == '1') even1++;

    } else { // odd index

        if (c == '0') odd0++;

        else if (c == '1') odd1++;

    }

}

Then compute the two options:

int option1 = len_third - (even0 + odd1);

int option2 = len_third - (even1 + odd0);

int result = (option1 < option2) ? option1 : option2;

Then print result.

Putting all together.

Now, putting all the code into a single C program.

But need to handle all variables and steps.

Now, let's outline the code structure.

#include <stdio.h>

#include <string.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

int main() {

    // First part:

    int n, c =0;

    scanf("%d", &n);

    // Read n lines:

    for (int i=0; i <n; i++) {

        char line[1000];

        fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);

        int sum =0;

        char *token = strtok(line, " \t\n");

        while (token != NULL) {

            int num = atoi(token);

            sum += num;

            token = strtok(NULL, " \t\n");

        }

        if (sum >1) c++;

    }

    // Convert c to string for second step.

    char s_second[20];

    sprintf(s_second, "%d", c);

    // Second step processing:

    int len_second = strlen(s_second);

    int count_second[256] = {0};

    for (int i=0; i < len_second; i++) {

        count_second[s_second[i]]++;

    }

    int unique =0;

    for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

        if (count_second[i] >0) unique++;

    }

    char second_output[4]; // "Yes" or "No"

    if (unique !=2) {

        strcpy(second_output, "No");

    } else {

        int valid =1;

        for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

            if (count_second[i] !=0 && count_second[i] !=2) {

                valid =0;

                break;

            }

        }

        if (valid) {

            strcpy(second_output, "Yes");

        } else {

            strcpy(second_output, "No");

        }

    }

    // Third step processing:

    int len_third = strlen(second_output);

    int even0=0, even1=0, odd0=0, odd1=0;

    for (int i=0; i < len_third; i++) {

        char c = second_output[i];

        if (i%2 ==0) {

            if (c == '0') even0++;

            else if (c == '1') even1++;

        } else {

            if (c == '0') odd0++;

            else if (c == '1') odd1++;

        }

    }

    int option1 = len_third - (even0 + odd1);

    int option2 = len_third - (even1 + odd0);

    int result = (option1 < option2) ? option1 : option2;

    printf("%d\n", result);

    return 0;

}

Wait, but in the third step's processing, the code counts only '0's and '1's in even and odd indices. Other characters (like 'Y', 'e', 's', 'N', 'o') are not counted, so their contribution to the errors is added as (even not 0 or 1) and (odd not 1 or 0).

Wait, in the code above, for characters other than '0' or '1', they are not counted in even0, even1, etc. So for example, in even indices, if the character is 'Y', then it's not counted in even0 or even1, so the total even0 + even1 is less than the number of even indices. Thus, the errors would be accounted for.

Yes, because:

The total even indices are (len_third +1)/2 (if odd length) or len_third/2 (even).

The even0 counts how many are '0's, even1 counts '1's. The rest are other characters, so their contribution to the errors is (even indices count - (even0 + even1)).

Similarly for odd indices.

Thus, the code correctly calculates the errors.
